headline.main: Offering Comfort to the Sick and Blessings to Their Healers
headline.kicker: In the Trenches | The Hospital Chaplain
headline.print_headline: Offering Comfort to the Sick and Blessings to Their Healers
headline.content_kicker: In the Trenches | The Hospital Chaplain

docs.snippet: The Rev. Margaret A. Muncie ministers to hospital patients of all faiths, as well as the hospital staff.

docs.lead_paragraph: At 1 p.m. on a weekday, the emergency department at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Upper Manhattan is in full cry, with bays crowded, patients on stretchers lining the hallways, and paramedics bringing in more sick people. Time for the Rev. Margaret A. Muncie to work the floor. Not shy, this pastor with the clerical collar, the Ann Taylor blazer and the cheerful insistence of one whose own mother called her a steamroller. Among the first women ordained an Episcopal priest and a self-described ''Caucasian minority,'' she's an odd bird among the ethnically diverse staff and especially the patients, most of them black or Latino. But she keeps pecking her head behind curtains, parting gatherings of worried family members, impervious to startled looks of suspicion.

headline.main: Offering Comfort to the Sick and Blessings to Their Healers
